name: File_Description
value: Number, location and behavior/activities of sea otters along the Santa Barbara Coast

name: Dataset_Title
value: SBC LTER: Reef: Sightings of sea otters (Enhydra lutris) near Santa Barbara and Channel Islands, ongoing since 2007; Santa Barbara Coastal Long Term Ecological Research Project

name: Dataset_Location
value: ABUR: Arroyo Burro Reef is located on the Santa Barbara Channel near the mouth of Arroyo Burro Creek and Beach. Depth ranges from 5.4 to 7 meters.; AHND: Arroyo Hondo Reef is located on the Santa Barbara Channel near the east end of Gaviota State Park, CA. Depth ranges from -4.3m to -6.6 meters.; AQUE: Arroyo Quemado Reef: Arroyo Quemado Reef depth range from 5.4 m to 10.7 m. Reference on Land is close to US101/Arroyo Quemada Ln.; BULL: Builto: Bulito has three permanent transect: Transect I, III, VI. Depth Range from -5.5 to -7.3. Reference on land is close to Ranch Real road and Hollister Ranch road crossing section.; CARP: Carpinteria Reef is located on the Santa Barbara Channel offshore of the Carpinteria Salt Marsh. Depth range is from -2.2 to -8.8 meters; GOLB: Goleta Bay is located on the Santa Barbara Channel east of Goleta Pier. Depth range is -4.2 to -5 meters.; IVEE: Isla Vista (IV) Reef is located on the Santa Barbara Channel near the University of California Santa Barbara, CA. Depth range is from -8.2 to -8.8 meters.; MOHK: Mohawk Reef: Mohawk Reef depth ranges from 4.5m to 6.0 m. Reference on land is Mohawk Rd / Edgewater Way.; NAPL: Naples Reef is located on the Santa Barbara Channel near the community of Naples and Dos Pueblos Canyon, Santa Barbara County, CA. Depth ranges from -5.9 to -13.4 meters.; SCDI: Santa Cruz Island, Diablo; SCTW: Santa Cruz Island, Twin Harbor West; Fry's 1: Fry's 1 is north of the Fry's harbor anchorage on the north shore of Santa Cruz Island, CA.; Fry's 2: Fry's 2 is north of the Fry's harbor anchorage on the north shore of Santa Cruz Island, CA.; Fry's 3: Fry's 3 is north of the Fry's harbor anchorage on the north shore of Santa Cruz Island, CA.; Fern 1: Fern 1 is located on the west edge of a small headland east of Fry's Harbor.; Fern Offshore: Fern Offshore is located on the east edge of a small headland east of Fry's Harbor.; BC 1: The BC reef is the west side of Platt's Harbor. BC 1 is SE of the main point.; BC 2: The BC reef is the west side of Platt's Harbor. BC 2 is NW of the main point.; BC Point: The BC reef is the west side of Platt's Harbor. BC Point is  off a small outcrop.; Twin W: Twin Harbors, West. North shore, Santa Cruz Island, CA; Twin E: Twin Harbors, East. North shore, Santa Cruz Island, CA

name: Dataset_Abstract
value: <para>    These data describe the number, location and activity or behavior of    sea otters (<emphasis>Enhydra lutris</emphasis>) individuals    observed along the Santa Barbara Coast and local Channel Islands,    during SBC LTER field sampling. Observations began in 2007. Records    are collected regularly at SBC core sites and opportunistically    while research staff are underway or travelling between sites.    Locations are included, but some latitudes and longitudes are    approximate.  </para>; <para>The Santa Barbara Coastal LTER (SBC LTER) is an interdisciplinary research and education programestablished in April 2000 with the goal of developing a predictive understanding of how environmentaldrivers interact with terrestrial and oceanic processes to alter material flows and influence the ecology ofcoastal ecosystems. SBC LTER's principal study domain is the semi-arid coast and nearshore waters ofthe Santa Barbara Channel in southern California, and its diverse and productive marine forests of giantkelp (<emphasis>Macrocystis pyrifera</emphasis>) serve as the focal study ecosystem. Analyses of our long-term data haveidentified many of the environmental drivers and ecological processes underlying the production andcommunity dynamics of kelp forests. The research proposed to address this question is integrated in a conceptual frameworkthat focuses on the causes and ecological consequences of the dynamics of a relatively short-livedfoundation species in a setting of long-term climate change and human use.</para>

name: Dataset_Methods
value: <para>    California sea otter sightings were observed and recorded in the    event log in congruence with all other SBC sampling in the field.    Binoculars were used if the species identification was unclear. Sea    otter location, number, and behavior are recorded any time an    individual is sighted in the field. Often individuals are recorded    while SBC field technicians are en route to a site. Upon arrival to    a site, the surface is scanned for sea otters and binoculars are    used to distinguish otters from other marine mammals including    harbor seals and sea lions.  </para>

name: Dataset_People
